review.title: A proposal for ethically traceable artificial intelligence
review.abstract: Although the problem of assigning a critique of robotic behavior in near-unanimous agreement to human norms seems intractable, a starting point of such a framework is of the collection of knowledge a priori and experience a posteriori categorized in a set of judgments available to the intelligence, translated into computer code. If such an intersection were successful, an algorithm with ethically traceable behavior and cogent equivalence to human cognition is established. The process of framework development itself reveals avenues of improvement and optimization. This paper will propose the application of Kant's critique of reason to current perceptions of autonomous intelligent systems.

author: P. Domingo

references.title: Ethically aligned design, a vision for prioritizing human wellbeing with artificial intelligence and autonomous systems
author: IEEE Standards

referenceMentions.context: As is oft cited in the literature, a near-universal application of moral imperative in the field of artificial intelligence programming and observed runtime behavior is lacking, theoretical intuitions scattered among five “tribes” [1], existing competitively: Symbolists, evolutionists, Bayesians, analogizers, and connectionists approaching a singularity.

It seems poignantly relevant to introduce this concept now as we are formulating the most basic of laws and regulations for artificial intelligence and autonomous intelligent systems design and manufacture [3].

The process of framework development itself reveals avenues of improvement and optimization. This paper will propose the application of Kant’s critique of reason to current perceptions of autonomous intelligent systems.
